en_second_half: pass and the little crown of greenery which is all that remains of Duma Key, and I just couldn’t picture such a mass of snakes there.

en_first_half: They came closer still, and I saw there was a rattlesnake in each of the seats, squirming and coiling. They were bringing me the snakes as a gift, maybe. Or as a punishment. I had
en_second_half: been away when my son died, after all. My reason for going to Boston, trouble with an advertising account, was partly an excuse. I was angry about Donna’s affair. No, furious. I needed to cool down.

en_first_half: I said, “It’s a song about a woman who keeps looking for her long-gone lover. Mrs.
en_second_half: Bell liked to push around her twins, although they were also long-gone. They died years ago.”

en_first_half: Zane scratched his chin. “She must have been handy. Some women are. Just because you think your
en_second_half: kids are still alive forty years later doesn’t mean you can’t replace a washer or a windowpane.”

en_first_half: Zane didn’t reply. I didn’t, either, but I thought maybe the kids had liked it. Maybe it had
en_second_half: even lulled them off to sleep after a big day of playing and swimming. Squeak… pause… squeak… pause… squeak…

en_first_half: “That’s it. Although hyenas who rob a deceased person’s house usually do it because they
en_second_half: read the obituary, and who’s going to write an obituary for Mrs. Bell? She was alone.”

en_first_half: By the time I got back to the house, I was hungry. No, ravenous. I scrambled up four eggs and toasted another English muffin. Donna would have said my hunger was healthy, life-affirming, a spit in the eye of death, but maybe I was just hungry. Finding a
en_second_half: dead woman at the head of her driveway and waving away the buzzards who wanted to eat her must have burned a lot of calories. I couldn’t get her ruined face out of my mind, but I ate everything on my plate anyway, and this time held it down.

en_first_half: It was the shirts. Touching the shirts. And the part about Tad? Those were my own memories intruding on whatever vibe I’d been getting from those shirts. My son finding his way into
en_second_half: my strange state of seeing wasn’t surprising. He had died at about the same age as the Bell twins, and at close to the same time. Triplets instead of twins. Tragedy calling to tragedy.

en_first_half: He chuckled. “Got that right. Just put the stroller back and close the door. Deceased lady’s
en_second_half: keys are at the substation. Andy Pelley will pick em up. You remember who I’m talking about?”

en_first_half: Pelley took no chances. He took a mask out of his voluminous shorts and put it on as soon as we were inside. I got him icewater and poured myself more coffee. I thought about donning my own mask
en_second_half: and decided not to. I wanted him to see my whole face. We sat at the kitchen table. Each time he sipped his water he pulled the mask down, then returned it to its place. The mustache made it bulge.

en_first_half: “Crazy all over the world,” Pelley said. “Why would you come down here in
en_second_half: the summer, anyway? Most people don’t, unless they’ve got free coupons from Disney World.”

en_first_half: Devereaux began to shiver all over like a man suffering a fit of ague. His legs jittered and scissored. His back arched. His midsection rose from the couch and thumped
en_second_half: down and rose again. His feet tapdanced and he began to make a sound, mump-mump-mump, as if his lips were spitstuck and he was trying to get them open to articulate.

en_first_half: On Saturday night he sat on the deck overlooking the lake with a quart bottle of Old Tyme ginger ale. He woke up on Sunday morning with no decision
en_second_half: made, but with no hangover—a plus, but not enough. When he got back to Boston that evening, Sally Ann would be waiting to find out what he had decided.

en_first_half: Curry was the problem, that small town near the Maine–New Hampshire state
en_second_half: line where the Parkers and Allburtons had summer homes on adjoining lakefront lots.
